author: A_Brickset_user
title: A challenge!
review:
The Good:
-More lego compatible than the galidor happy meal toys.
-Interesting pieces that are challenging to find uses for(Head for a giant(minifig scale)alien, Feet for booster rockets, and a soccer ball spherical warp core?)

The Bad:
-That stupid kicking leg and the lack of an appendage on one side.
-Stickers, not only stickers but lousy ones.
-Doesnt really work.

The Ugly:
-The fact that at the time lego wouldnt give actual bricks in macdonalds releases

author: legoman4694
title: i dont see whats wrong
review: you get a guy a ball and a card board goal. its a kids meal what did you expect? and expertly built master piece? its just some thing to entertain you while your at the resturant! you should seewhat lego is did more recently at mcdonalds! they made bionicle inika and piraka (i have a few) figures. they arnt lego at all! no building no bricks they cant even attach to anything. you should be thankful for this because lego isnt doing very good sets there now!

author: TameTheDragon94
title: The Soccer Player With Three Legs!
review:
Introduction:

I was at the same flea market that I found Euripides in (see my other review), and while looking through a box I discovered a copy of this set. The owner was only asking for a dollar for it, so naturally I accepted. Let’s get on with my review, shall we?

The Figure Itself:

This is one strange set. It consists of 4 pieces: a head & torso, legs you can’t move, a third leg (for the play feature), and an extremely large soccer ball. I don’t know if the head and hair can be taken apart, and I have decided not to check due to my fear of breaking it. The figure is made of decent quality plastic, and the only printing is on the face. There is a molded Lego logo on the back of the torso piece, as well as on the soccer ball. The ball is made of two pieces screwed together. The set comes with two stickers: one “4” to place on the torso, and another one to place on the third leg. I can’t tell what it is, but basically it’s a bunch of grey lines on a white background. This set also comes with a paper goal for you to kick the ball into, which is a mediocre piece.

Building Experience:

You don’t really build this set, you just connect the parts. The instructions are confusing, and I have yet to figure out how to set up the goal.

Parts:

The only way this set can be used with actual lego is the fact that there are anti-studs on the bottom of the feet, though I have yet to test this on a baseplate. The other parts are basically unusable. Still, they are exclusive to this set (I believe).

Playability:

Small children could have a “ball” with this set (see what I did there?!). The play feature is well done, and kicking the ball around is a little fun. You just press down on the head, and the third leg kicks. Other than that, this set is pretty boring. It is a free McDonald’s toy, so who can complain?

Conclusion:

This is a semi-high quality Lego toy from McDonald’s. It is worth picking up, because of all the weird and exclusive parts you get with it. But on eBay, they sell for a lot more than I bought it for, and I don’t think it’s worth more than 3$, so only buy if you find it dirt cheap like I did. If you ever go to a flea market or antique store, it might be worth digging through the old happy meal toy box. Thank you for reading my review.
